 There are steps for something to be considered for teaching in a science class. These steps are often referred to as the scientific method. They are:
 
 1. Purpose (a question or a problem to be solved) 
 2. Research (A summary of your information (facts) on the topic) 
 3. Hypothesis (what you think the answer will be; an educated guess) 
 4. Materials (a list of everything you need to complete your project) 
 5. Procedure (steps to carry out controlled experiments) 
 6. Results (your observations, what happened during the experiment) 
 7. Conclusion (the answer--if you found one--to the original question or problem; was your hypothesis correct? This conclusion can be a theory [a best explanation] or fact [the only explanation])

 Dembski has admitted that his explanatory filter (stated in The Design Inference) can yield false negatives; in other words, that one can conclude that something is of natural origin when in fact it was designed by intelligence. However, Dembski maintains that there are no false positives. This has been shown to be untrue. Several reviews of and essays about Dembski's work have offered several examples of the application of the explanatory filter that yield false positives. So what good is it if there is no way to determine false results, both negative and positive?
 
 Dembski, as a result of criticism of his process, significantly changed the definitions of elements of the explanatory filter. For example, in his initial renditions of his "theory" (as in The Design Inference), Dembski defines specification as consisting of two necessary components: detachability and delimitation. And detachability, in turn, necessarily comprises two subcomponents: conditional independence and tractability.
 
 Well, that would be well and good, if it worked, but it seems that even Dembski found some problems in his theory. In No Free Lunch, he declares that tractability is no longer a constituent of detachability. He says, "...I have retained the conditional independence but removed the tractability condition." Why? Dembski doesn't say. It seems that the only necessary component of detachability is now conditional independence. Dembski now says that tractability is no longer necessary within detachability but should be moved to his Generic Chance Elimination Argument.
 
 Further, the delimitation condition that was prominently discussed in The Design Inference, is no longer used in No Free Lunch. Again, Dembski offers no explanation as to why this necessary condition has been dropped.
 
 Dembski, always confident of his own genius, also proposes, in addition to the "three traditional laws of thermodynamics," a fourth law of thermodynamics. It seems that no physicist or chemist has noticed this "fourth law," but Dembski has. But it seems to me that if someone is going to represent their expertise on thermodynamics that he should be aware that there already are 4 laws of thermodynamics. Not only that, Dembski's "4th law" addresses phenomena that have already been covered by the 2nd law, and therefore, even if it were correct, would not be a new law. However, Dembski's new law actually contradicts the 2nd law.
